BCC Mobile Money Regulatory Framework:

Foundational Regulation:
Law No. 18/019 of July 9, 2018 on payment systems
- Aims to modernize, secure, and structure financial sector
- Confers extensive supervisory powers to BCC
- Mobile Money as pillar of financial inclusion

Instruction No. 42 (March 9, 2020):
- Governs practical modalities of electronic money
- Targets Electronic Money Establishments (EME)
- Defines operating principles
- Participant obligations
- Requires prior BCC approval for operating electronic money system

2024 Development - Instruction No. 58 (September 4, 2024):
- Reinforces interoperability of systems
- Requires operators to connect to Swift Monétique National (national electronic payment network)
- Facilitates inter-network transactions

Legal Entity Structure:
Regulations require distinction of legal entities. Although often managed by telecom operators (Vodacom, Orange, Airtel, Africell), Congolese legislation requires distinct entities for electronic money issuance (e.g., M-Pesa RDC SA, Airtel Money RDC SA). EMEs supervised by BCC, isolating financial risks from telecommunications.

Market Share 2024:
- Vodacom (M-Pesa): $168.5 million (46%)
- Airtel: $137.2 million (37.5%)
- Orange: $58.5 million (16%)
- Africell: $1.7 million (0.5%)

#### DOCUMENT 40: DRC De-Dollarization Policy 2024-2025
```
SOURCE_URL: https://www.legal500.com/developments/thought-leadership/overview-of-foreign-exchange-regulations-applicable-in-the-democratic-republic-of-congo-in-2025/
RETRIEVED: 2025-12-03

DATE_OF_DOCUMENT: 2025

CONTENT:
De-Dollarization Measures (Fully Effective 2025):

Price Display Requirements:
- All merchants, service providers, commercial entities must display prices exclusively in CDF
- Display in foreign currencies: Fine up to equivalent of USD 5,000
- Recurrence: Temporary administrative closure of establishment

Electronic Payment Terminals:
- Since June 2024: All EPTs configured exclusively in national currency
- Banking establishments and mobile operators must reconfigure payment terminals
- Applies to online payment platforms and mobile applications
- Obligation for automatic conversion of foreign currencies to CDF at official rate

Fiscal Payments:
- All fiscal and parafiscal obligations must be paid in national currency
- Tax administrations no longer accept foreign currency payments
- Applies to extractive sector companies (previously had exemptions)

Contract Requirements:
- All contracts between residents must be denominated in Congolese francs
- Includes commercial and residential lease contracts (traditionally in USD)

BCC Regulatory Authority:
Central Bank of Congo (BCC) remains principal regulatory authority for foreign exchange market.

Pursuant to Organic Law No. 18/027:
BCC possesses extensive prerogatives to issue instructions and regulations. Role centers on definition and implementation of monetary policy, including management of exchange rate regime.

Exchange Bureaux:
- Approximately 230 authorized exchange bureaux (2025)
- Concentrated in Kinshasa, Lubumbashi, Goma
- Minimum capital: Equivalent to USD 50,000
- Monthly reporting required
- AML standards compliance mandatory
- Operations outside official circuit considered illegal, subject to penal sanctions

Transaction Requirements:
Payments exceeding USD 10,000 must be executed within banking system, unless no banking presence.

Government Repatriation Limits:
Mining companies must repatriate 60% of export earnings to DRC bank; remaining 40% can be in foreign bank.
```

DRC Monetary Policy Context:

Dollarization Extent:
IMF 2024 consultation found approximately 85-90% of bank loans and 95% of deposits denominated in foreign currency (mainly dollars).

Central Bank Policy Rate:
BCC maintained 25% policy rate since 2023—highest in sub-Saharan Africa—to curb inflation and stabilize CDF.

Results:
- Inflation fell from 23.8% (late 2023) to 8.5% (mid-2025)
- International reserves: 11.8 weeks of imports (June 2025), up from 10.0 weeks (2024)

Exchange Rate:
- Congolese franc depreciated 8.7% against US dollar
- Inflation: 11.3%
- Banking sector remained profitable with expanding credit and declining NPLs

BCC Managed Float Regime:
Combined with foreign exchange interventions to accumulate reserves.

Economic Reality:
DRC is dollarized economy. Most institutions accept U.S. dollars or Congolese francs.

New Governor (2025):
André Wameso stated restoring credibility of Congolese franc and rolling back decades of dollarization will define his term. Argued monetary sovereignty impossible when households, firms, government treat dollar as default unit of account, store of value, medium of exchange.
